19 / You can also see the distribution of negative and positive scores: https://t.co/lsf75oxBNa

18/ All three - pos, neu, neg. 

I tend to avoid negative social media posts in general, so I wasn't surprised to see more positive than negative sentiments. https://t.co/kLuklVCA5c
17 / Negativity scores: https://t.co/QlDYYdWEaK

16/ We can finally see polarity scores for each sentence from 14 yrs of FB posts w/ #ggplot2

Here are positivity scores: https://t.co/l7aC2sJJuv

15/ Transitioning to R #Rstats for data transformation and visualization #dataviz (personal pref)

We'll read both csv, create a new index-column, then use that to join the two df.

We'll use pivot_wider so each polarity score (pos, neu, neg) has its own column https://t.co/wsekqxwp73

14/ This next part is a fairly hacky. I created two lists to store sentences and their respective polarity scores separately. 

Then using pandasüêº, I turned those lists into data frames and saved to CSV (we'll then transition to R) https://t.co/ECkSWC9bSp
13/ You can see the genesis of üêç #python NLTK Vader module in the first author's dissertation: https://t.co/J2i8hUWz88

12/ Fun fact: Vader has an extensive dictionary where words are given a polarity score. Repo: https://t.co/CbJlzqsvXy

The process of creating the ratings is reminiscent of psychology research. Using human expert judges to rate, then check for inter-rater reliability.

11/ Now we're going to do Rule-based Sentiment Analysis with #python VADER module (Valence, Aware, Dictionary and sEntiment Reasoner).

My facebook data is unlabelled, so Machine Learning is not an option here.

10/ Counting sentence frequency can also yield some insights üí° for example:

https://t.co/BWzjscG6iJ

9/ For those that want to go through the process of Text Normalization, here's the code:

Also visit the original article by Matthew Mayo: https://t.co/xtZqenH3NF https://t.co/sB4DR66r1i

8/ I did it with, then without, normalization to compare. You can see some minor differences 

(we're skipping ahead a bit with this chart) https://t.co/CL7Bqt0K1M

7/ For individual words, we would normalize to level the playing field, but Python's Vader module can analyze sentences w/ punctuation, capitalization and even emojis and emoticons (so we *don't* want to normalize the text here).

6/ Next is tokenization. nltk.sent_tokenize() will detect escape sequences (\n) and split the text into individual sentences. 

This organizes your data from one big mass into individual sentences. https://t.co/oogzp9wILV
5/ Multiple nested loops and conditionals to dig through and grab the FB post text. https://t.co/hmTZQsdCOh

4/ Next, extract the data you want (see 'post' key). You may want the time stamp; for this project, I only wanted text.

Multiple nested loops to grab a specific value once we convert json -> dictionary. https://t.co/1ZB5grUEFe

3/ With {rjson}üì¶ you'll move towards turning data into data frame, which is great (and we're headed there), but I wanted to try üêç NLTK for text analysis, so we'll want to stay in #Python a bit longer.

2/ Use Python's json module to read in data.

Also available in #Rstats with rjson üì¶ (I wanted the practice with Python and I find looping lists and dictionaries to grab specific parts ideal for learning ). https://t.co/9ugZW1XfRW

6/ 

Although the problem exists because a digital *anything* makes it is exceedingly easy to duplicate, the solution requires much more than a software-oriented fix. 

And that's why Bitcoin is also fascinating.

5/ 

The challenge is figuring out how to prevent someone from duplicating their digital currencies, paying a merchant and then retaining the original to spend...again...and again. 

This is the core problem Bitcoin solves.

4/

How can a digital file have value if it can be so easily copied and shared? 

Once you go from digital songs üéµ ‚û°Ô∏è digital currency üí≤, the importance of this question is magnified. 

Now, you go from intellectual copyright infringement üéµ ‚û°Ô∏è a double-spend problem üí≤

3/

Naturally, this changed everything for the music industry and although Metallica and other artists sued Napster, forcing it into bankruptcy. Digital Audio files that could be shared peer-to-peer was inevitable. 

There was no going back.

2/

I had a Sony MD walkman that could record, directly from my computer, any mp3 file that was playing through Winamp. 

Someone half a world a way could attend a concert, record and upload a live version of my favorite song and I could enjoy it...for free. https://t.co/P9gMxKPOpM

@dvpme My *assumption is that we want tweets that get people to click on our User Profile. And I downloaded my own data from the past 5 months to see what had the strongest correlation with User Profile clicks. For my data, if someone "liked" my tweet, they were more likely to visit my-

6/ 

At least in my case, the metrics that most impacted user profile clicks were (in descending order):
- likes
- detail expands
- media engagement
- replies
- retweets
- hashtag clicks
- url clicks

fin/

- that he created a style of play

In fact, he was pretty open about copying MJ...for skill.

Kobe copied for skill. 

What skills?

- change in direction
- keep the ball from defenders
- stopping to get a quick shot off
- backing up a defender to create separation
- pivoting into a fadeaway
- hesitating into a fadeaway
- bump and turn

Here's a YT clip called "Identical Plays" showing Kobe executing identical moves from MJ. 

A student of the game, he copied the best. A couple things to note here üßµ

7/

Try as she might, she couldn't negotiate out of "one" dance. 

When the action is so small, you feel silly not doing it. 

That's when I knew we had a minimum-non-negotiable unit of activity. 

That's when it has a shot at developing into a habit. 

fin/

6/
She comes home from work one day, too many meetings üíÄ. 

She's drained. 

With her shoe in hand, I said: "One dance"

5/

Nope. Just 1‚É£song. Then we celebrate ü•≥

4/
